# Introduction to prediction

.pull-left[
- So far, we had been focusing on **.darkorange[causal inference]**:

  - Estimating an effect and "predicting" a counterfactual (what if?)
  
- Now, we will focus on **.darkorange[prediction]**:

  - Estimate/predict outcomes under specific conditions.
]

.center[
![](https://media.giphy.com/media/3orieSdZDhn7I6gViw/giphy.gif)
]
]

---
# Differences between inference and prediction

- Inference $\rightarrow$ focus on **.darkorange[covariate]**
  
  - **.darkorange[Interpretability]** of model.
  
- Prediction $\rightarrow$ focus on **.darkorange[outcome variable]**

  - **.darkorange[Accuracy]** of model.
  
.box-2[Both can be complementary!]

# Bias vs Variance

.box-4["There are no free lunches in statistics"]

--

- Not one method dominates others: Context/dataset dependent.

- Remember that the goal of prediction is to have a method that is accurate in predicting outcomes on **.darkorange[previously unseen data]**.

  - **.darkorange[Validation set approach:]** Training and testing data

--

.box-2[Balance between flexibility and accuracy]


---
# Bias vs Variance

.box-2[Variance]

.box-2t["[T]he amount by which f would change if we estimated it using a different training dataset"]

--

.box-7[Bias]

.box-7t["[E]rror introduced by approximating a real-life problem with a model"]


---

.center2[
.box-5LA[Which models do you think are higher variance: More flexible models or less flexible models?]
]

---
# Bias vs. Variance: The  ultimate battle

- In inference, **.darkorange[bias >> variance]**

- In prediction, we care about **.darkorange[both]**:

  - Measures of accuracy will have both bias and variance.
  
  .box-4[Trade-off at different rates]

---
# How do we measure accuracy?

Different measures:

- Remember $Adj-R^2$?

--

- **.darkorange[Mean Squared Error (MSE)]**: *Can be decomposed into variance and bias terms*
$$MSE = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i-\hat{f}(x_i))^2$$

---
# How do we measure accuracy?

Different measures:


- **.darkorange[Akaike Information Criterion (AIC)]**: *Balances goodness of fit while penalizing for number of predictors*

$$AIC = 2(d+1) - 2\log(\hat{L}) \overset{OLS}{=} \frac{1}{n\hat{\sigma}^2}(RSS + 2d\hat{\sigma}^2)$$

--

- **.darkorange[Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC)]**: *Balances goodness of fit while penalizing for number of predictors*

$$BIC = (d+1)\log(n) - 2\log(\hat{L}) \overset{OLS}{=} \frac{1}{n\hat{\sigma}^2}(RSS + \log(n)d\hat{\sigma}^2)$$
<br>
where $\hat{\sigma}^2$: Estimate of the error variance (full model), $d$: Number of predictors, $\hat{L}$: Maximum likehood estimate.

# Is flexibility always better?

```{r bias_variance, fig.height=6, fig.width=12, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message = FALSE}
set.seed(100)

n <- 100
x <- rnorm(n, 0, 1)
y <- x^3 - x^2 + x + 1 + rnorm(n, 0, 5)

d <- data.frame(id = 1:100, x = x, y = y)

id_train <- sample(d$id, nrow(d)*0.8)
id_test <- d$id[-id_train]

d_train <- d[id_train,]
d_test <- d[id_test,]

lm1 <- lm(y ~ x, data = d_train)
lm2 <- lm(y ~ I(x^3)+I(x^2) + x, data = d_train)

library(splines)

knots <- quantile(d_train$x, p = seq(0.05,0.95, 0.05))

s1 <- lm (y ~ bs(x, df=20), data = d_train)

pred_lm1 <- lm1 %>% predict(d_test)
pred_lm2 <- lm2 %>% predict(d_test)
pred_s1 <- s1 %>% predict(d_test)

RMSE = function(m, o){
  sqrt(mean((m - o)^2))
}


pred_lm1_t <- lm1 %>% predict(d_train)
pred_lm2_t <- lm2 %>% predict(d_train)
pred_s1_t <- s1 %>% predict(d_train)

acc <- data.frame(RMSE_lm1 = RMSE(pred_lm1, d_test$y),
                  RMSE_lm2 = RMSE(pred_lm2, d_test$y),
                  RMSE_s1 = RMSE(pred_s1, d_test$y),
                  RMSE_lm1_t = RMSE(pred_lm1_t, d_train$y),
                  RMSE_lm2_t = RMSE(pred_lm2_t, d_train$y),
                  RMSE_s1_t = RMSE(pred_s1_t, d_train$y),
                  flex = 2)

g1 <- ggplot(data = d_train, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(pch=21,color="dark grey", fill="white", size = 4) +
  geom_line(aes(y = pred_lm1_t, x=x, color = "#5601A4"), lwd=1.2)+
  geom_line(aes(y = pred_lm2_t, x=x, color = "#BF3984"), lwd=1.2)+
  geom_line(aes(y = pred_s1_t, x=x, color = "#FCCE25"), lwd=1.2)+
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#5601A4", "#BF3984", "#FCCE25"), name = "Models", label=c("Linear","Cubic","Spline")) +
  theme_bw()+
  theme_ipsum_fsc()+
  xlab("X") + ylab("Y") + ggtitle("Fit on training dataset") + 
    theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        #panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank())+
        #axis.line = element_blank())+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10),legend.position=c(0.9,0.2),
        legend.title = element_text(size=14),
        legend.text = element_text(size=14),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))


g2 <- ggplot(data = data.frame(x = c(2,4,20), y = c(acc$RMSE_lm1,acc$RMSE_lm2,acc$RMSE_s1)),
              aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_smooth(aes(color = "#E16462"),fill="white",method = "loess")+
  geom_smooth(data = data.frame(x = c(2,4,20), y = c(acc$RMSE_lm1_t,acc$RMSE_lm2_t,acc$RMSE_s1_t)),
              aes(x = x, y = y,color = "dark grey"), method = "loess")+
  geom_point(data = acc, aes(x = flex, y = RMSE_lm1_t, fill="#5601A4"), color="white", pch=21, size = 4) +
  geom_point(data = acc, aes(x = flex, y = RMSE_lm1, fill="#5601A4"), color="white", pch=22, size = 4) +
  geom_point(data = acc, aes(x = 4, y = RMSE_lm2_t, fill="#BF3984"),color="white", pch=21,size = 4) +
  geom_point(data = acc, aes(x = 4, y = RMSE_lm2, fill="#BF3984"),color="white", pch=22, size = 4) +
  geom_point(data = acc, aes(x = 20, y = RMSE_s1, fill="#FCCE25"),color="white", pch=21,size = 4) +
  geom_point(data = acc, aes(x = 20, y = RMSE_s1_t, fill="#FCCE25"),color="white", pch=22, size = 4) +
  theme_bw()+
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#5601A4", "#BF3984", "#FCCE25"), name = "Models", label=c("Linear","Cubic","Spline")) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#E16462", "dark grey"), name = "Dataset", label=c("Testing","Training")) +
  theme_ipsum_fsc()+xlim(0,20)+
  xlab("Flexibility") + ylab("RMSE") + ggtitle("RMSE for training and testing dataset") + 
    theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        #panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank())+
        #axis.line = element_blank())+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size = 10),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=16),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size = 10),legend.position=c(0.9,0.5),
        legend.title = element_text(size=14),
        legend.text = element_text(size=14),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))
  
g1 + g2
```

# Is flexibility always better?

# Example: Let's predict pre-churn!

- You work at Disney+ and you know that a good measure for someone at risk of unsubscribing is the times they've logged in the past week:

```{r, echo=FALSE}
library(scales)

set.seed(100)

n <- 5000

female <- sample(c(0,1),n,replace=TRUE, prob=c(0.5,0.5))
mandalorian <- sample(c(0,1),n,replace=TRUE, prob=c(0.3,0.7))
city <- sample(c(0,1),n,replace=TRUE, prob=c(0.15,0.85))

age <- rnorm(n,45,15)

age <- round(rescale(age, to=c(18,73)),0)

#logins <- sample(seq(0,10),n,replace=TRUE, prob=c(0.19,0.09,0.09,0.08,0.07,0.07,0.06,0.05,0.04,0.03,0.23))

xb_l <- 2.5 - 5*mandalorian + city*2 + rnorm(n, 0, 1)

q <- quantile(xb_l, prob = seq(0,1,0.1))

logins <- ifelse(xb_l < q[2]+1,0,ifelse(xb_l< q[3]+0.05, 1, ifelse(xb_l < q[4], 2,
                                                            ifelse(xb_l < q[5], 3, ifelse(xb_l < q[6]-0.2, 4,
                                                                                          ifelse(xb_l < q[7], 5, ifelse(xb_l < -90,
                                                                                                                        6, ifelse(xb_l < q[8]-0.2, 7, ifelse(xb_l < q[9]-0.2, 8, ifelse(xb_l < q[10]-0.5, 9, 10))))))))))

xb <- 0.15 - 0.01*city + mandalorian*0.2 + (logins==0)*0.1 + rnorm(n, 0, 0.05)

prob <- rescale(xb, to = c(0.01,0.52))

unsubscribe <- rep(NA, n)

for(i in 1:n){
  
  unsubscribe[i] <- sample(c(0,1), 1, replace = TRUE, prob = c(1-prob[i],prob[i]))

}

disney <- data.frame(id = 1:n,
                     female = female,
                     city = city,
                     age = age,
                     logins = logins,
                     mandalorian = mandalorian,
                     unsubscribe = unsubscribe)

disney <- read.csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week10/2_ModelSelection/data/disney.csv")

# Divide data: 80% vs 20% split

set.seed(100) #Always set seed for replication!

n <- nrow(disney)

train <- sample(1:n, n*0.8) #randomly select 80% of the rows

train.data <- disney[train,] #use only the rows that were selected for training

test.data <- disney[-train,] #the rest are used for testing

### Simple model
lm_simple <- lm(logins ~ mandalorian + city, data = train.data) #Train the model on the TRAINING DATASET

### Complex model
lm_complex <- lm(logins ~ female + city + age + I(age^2) + mandalorian, data = train.data) #Train the model on the TRAINING DATASET


# Estimate RMSE for these models on the TRAINING dataset:
# For simple model:
pred_simple_train <- lm_simple %>% predict(train.data, type="response")
#RMSE(pred_simple_train, train.data$unsubscribe)

# For complex model:
pred_complex_train <- lm_complex %>% predict(train.data, type="response")
#RMSE(pred_complex_train, train.data$unsubscribe)

## Question: Which model is better?

# Estimate RMSE for these models on the TESTING dataset:
# For simple model:
pred_simple_test <- lm_simple %>% predict(test.data, type="response")
#RMSE(pred_simple_test, test.data$unsubscribe)

# For complex model:
pred_complex_test <- lm_complex %>% predict(test.data, type="response")
#RMSE(pred_complex_test, test.data$unsubscribe)
```

# Two candidates: Simple vs Complex

- **.darkorange[Simple Model]**:

  $$logins_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1\times mandalorian + \beta_2 \times city + \varepsilon_i$$
  
- **.darkorange[Complex Model]**:

$$
\begin{aligned}
logins_i =& \beta_0 + \beta_1\times mandalorian + \beta_2\times age + \beta_3\times age^2 +\\
&\beta_4\times city + \beta_5\times female + \varepsilon_i
\end{aligned}
$$

# Cross-Validation

- To avoid using only **.darkorange[one training and testing dataset]**, we can iterate over *k-fold* division of our data:

.center[
![:scale 80%](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/maibennett/sta235/main/exampleSite/content/Classes/Week10/2_ModelSelection/images/cv.png)]

---
# Cross-Validation

**.darkorange[Procedure for *k-fold* cross-validation]**:

  1. Divide your data in *k-folds* (usually, $K=5$ or $K=10$).
  
  2. Use $k=1$ as the testing data and $k=2,..,K$ as the training data.
  
  3. Calculate the accuracy measure $A_k$ on the testing data.
  
  4. Repeat for each $k$.
  
  5. Average $A_k$ for all $k \in K$.

--

Main advantage: Use the entire dataset for training **.darkorange[AND]** testing.

Extreme scenario: $K=n$ $\rightarrow$ Leave One Out Cross-Validation (LOOCV)

---

.center2[
.box-7LA[Do you think 5-fold CV is better or worse than a LOOCV?]
]

```{r, eval = FALSE}
lm_simple
```

# Stepwise selection

- We have seen how to choose between some given models. **.darkorange[But what if we want to test all possible models?]**

- **.darkorange[Stepwise selection]**: Computationally-efficient algorithm to select a model based on the data we have (subset selection).

--

Algorithm for forward stepwise selection:

1. Start with the *null model*, $M_0$ (no predictors)

2. For $k=0, ..., p-1$:
  (a) Consider all $p-k$ models that augment $M_k$ with one additional predictor.
  (b) Choose the *best* among these $p-k$ models and call it $M_{k+1}$.
  
3. Select the single best model from $M_{0},...,M_p$ using CV.

.source[Backwards stepwise follows the same procedure, but starts with the full model.]

---

.center2[
.box-2LA[Will forward stepwise subsetting yield the same results as backwards stepwise selection?]
]

# How do we do stepwise selection in R?
.small[
```{r}
library(leaps)

regfit.fwd <- regsubsets(logins ~ . - unsubscribe, data=disney, method = "forward")
summary(regfit.fwd)
```
]

# How do we do stepwise selection in R?
.small[
```{r}
set.seed(100)

train.control <- trainControl(method = "cv", number = 10) #set up a 10-fold cv

lm.fwd <- train(logins ~ . - unsubscribe, data = disney, method = "leapForward",#<< 
                tuneGrid = data.frame(nvmax = 1:5), trControl = train.control)#<<
lm.fwd$results
```
